Array.Value: Use [Jump] to jump across an empty tile or climb upto 2 tiles.
Use [MoveNext] to <color=#EA6B48>switch</color> the target in the Aim.

Use [Interaction] to <color=#EA6B48>interact</color> with the target in the Aim.

While wielding a weapon, use [Interaction] to <color=#EA6B48>attack</color> the enemy.
Use [DetailCheck] to check a ratizen or a structure's <color=#EA6B48>details</color>.

Use [Command] to give <color=#EA6B48>orders</color> to ratizens.

If there are many orders in queue, a ratizen will follow them in order:

Repair, demolish, build, gather, mine, and pick up.
While pressing [Interaction], use [AllDir] to order actions on <color=#EA6B48>all targets</color> in the area.

Use [WeaponOn] to change between the <color=#EA6B48>admin mode</color> and the <color=#C83232>battle mode</color>.

In the battle mode, use [Interaction] to <color=#EA6B48>attack</color> an enemy in front.

Resource objects can be <sprite name=FS_Gathering><color=#EA6B48>gathered</color> through interactions or commands.

They will <color=#EA6B48>grow</color> back again after a certain time, but will not grow back when completely <color=#EA6B48>removed</color>.

The growth of resource objects can be affected by the <color=#EA6B48>weather</color> and <color=#EA6B48>seasons</color>.

Tile objects are the resources that can be destroyed either by interaction or by command <sprite name=FS_Mining><color=#EA6B48>Mining</color>.

Mined tiles drop a certain amount of resources and do not recover over time.

Structures can be built by using the command window. Enough resources in the storages are required to place the <sprite name=FS_Blueprint><color=#EA6B48>Blueprint</color>.

After placing the blueprints, transport the resources from <sprite name=FS_Base><color=#EA6B48>storage</color> to proceed with construction.

The blueprints cannot be placed where other objects are located.

You can accept new migrants with <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>City Entrance</color>.

If there are no ratizens you want to accept, you can send them back and wait for the next group.

You can enact tax laws with <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Code Stone</color>.

Tax laws levy taxes on eligible objects at specific times each day.

You can collect the <sprite name=FS_Tax><color=#EA6B48>tax</color> by interacting with the taxed ratizen.

This action can be delegated to ratizens with <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Tax Office</color>.

The Ratizen assigned to <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Tax Office</color> gathers tax one by one from the one with the highest unpaid tax.

<sprite name=FS_Food><color=#EA6B48>Food</color> can be produced through gathering and production.

Basic food resources can be produced through <sprite name=FS_RawMaterials><color=#EA6B48>Raw Material Structures</color>, such as farms and pastures.

Some resources can be crafted into advanced items with certain <sprite name=FS_Production><color=#EA6B48>Production Buildings</color>.

You can begin research with <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Research Table</color>.

New <sprite name=FS_Blueprint><color=#EA6B48>blueprints </color> can be acquired through the research, but <sprite name=FS_ResearchPoint><color=#EA6B48>research points</color> will be required.

Each structures requires different research points and prior researchs, so please check carefully before researching.

To check statistics, use [Command2]<color=#EA6B48>Administration</color> function.

The <sprite name=FS_Statistics><color=#EA6B48>Statistics</color> window has city-wide information about structures and ratizens.

When certain conditions are met, the ratizen will display a <sprite name=FS_QuestMark><color=#EA6B48>exclamation mark</color> and follow the leader to make their request.

At this point, you can confirm the request by interacting with the ratizen, and depending on your choice, you will receive different <color=#EA6B48>missions and rewards</color>.

When receiving a request, a mission indicator will be created in the upper left corner of the screen.

Rewards are given for completing the missions, but some missions will have a <color=#EA6B48>time limit</color>.
You can undo issued commands with the <sprite name=FS_Cancel><color=#EA6B48>Cancel</color> command in the command window.

Structures can be demolished at any time with the <sprite name=FS_Demolition><color=#EA6B48>Demolish order</color>.

When demolished, 100% of the resources used to construct the structure are dropped.

Ratizens prioritize the demolition orders, but the leader may proceed directly after the order is given.

You can hunt animals in <color=#C83232>Combat Mode</color> via <color=#EA6B48>Mode Change</color>.

To order ratizens to hunt animals, assign them to <sprite name=FS_RawMaterials><color=#EA6B48>Hunter's hut</color>.

To <color=#EA6B48>produce</color> new resources, a ratizen must be placed in a production structure.

Some production structures can produce various resources, so which to produce must be chosen.

Make sure that only the necessary items are produced.

For some structures, adjusting detailed settings is possible with [LeftDir2][RightDir2] while <color=#EA6B48>Checking details</color>.

This feature allows you to limit the range of the service or other variable functions depends on the structures.

You can adjust the field of view with [ZoomIn][ZoomOut].

Also, you can return to the default view at any time by using [ZoomDefault].

Adjust your field of view to manage your city more comfortably.

<sprite name=FS_Citizen><color=#EA6B48>Ratizens</color> are the core component of the city, and also the reason why the city exists.

Ratizens assist the leader in actions and, if conditions are met, carry out the orders.

Ratizens show various behaviors depending on their status and happiness, so let's manage them well.

<sprite name=FS_Happiness><color=#EA6B48>Happiness</color> is a measured value of how satisfied the ratizens are with the life in the city.

Ratizens with higher happiness have higher labor efficiency, and ratizens with low happiness might make somewhat extreme choices.

<sprite name=FS_Stamina><color=#EA6B48>Stamina</color> is the energy that ratizens need to act.

Generally, it can be recovered by sleeping.

Ratizens who are too low on Stamina will faint and fall into a deep sleep.

<sprite name=FS_Food><color=#EA6B48>Food</color> is a measure of how well the ratizens are fed.

Ratizens who run out of food will begin to starve, and they will die when starved for too long.

<sprite name=FS_Fun><color=#EA6B48>Joy</color> is a measure of how well the ratizens are enjoying their lives in the city.

Even with adequate supplies of food and sanitation, ratizens will become dissatisfied with nothing to enjoy.

<sprite name=FS_Cleanliness><color=#EA6B48>Hygiene</color> is a measure of how clean the people are.

Poor hygiene leads to illness, and the illness could result in epidemics.

<sprite name=FS_Life><color=#EA6B48>Necessities</color> indicates how many items are supplied to a ratizen to live.

Each necessities have their own durability and must be consumed again after a certain time.

Ratizens with more necessities could rise to a higher class.

<sprite name=FS_Property><color=#EA6B48>Income</color> is the amount of money that a ratizen earns per day.

Ratizens with higher incomes have greater freedom in consumption, and have a higher level of happiness according to their income satisfaction.

<sprite name=FS_Tax><color=#EA6B48>Tax</color> is an amount of money levied on a ratizen through the tax laws.

Taxes can be collected through tax offices and direct collection.

Depending on how much they are taxed, ratizens have tax satisfaction, and the lower the tax satisfaction, the less happy they are.

<color=#EA6B48>State</color> is the situation that the ratizen is currently in, and some actions could be restricted for ratizens with a certain state.

Ratizens placed in the restricted situations may not be controlled even on direct orders from the Leader.

<color=#EA6B48>Status Effect</color> is any ability effect the ratizen is currently receiving.

Depending on the status effect, various effects can be granted, such as increasing the strength of ratizens or slowing their movement speed.

Status effects do not restrict ratizens' actions.

<sprite name=FS_Grade3><color=#EA6B48>Social Class</color> is a distinct group of ratizens, determined by their wealth and level of consumption.

Ratizens who sufficiently meet various factors, such as wealth and <sprite name=FS_Life><color=#EA6B48>necessities</color>, will get into higher classes and increased labor efficiency.

Ratizens in higher classes usually have higher levels of satisfaction than lower-class ratizens, but they might get dissatisfied due to the different standards.

When <sprite name=FS_Happiness><color=#EA6B48>Happiness</color> gets low, ratizen might get into internal conflict.

The ratizen with <sprite name=FS_DevilTemptation><color=#EA6B48>Internal Conflict</color> might commit crime.

If a ratizen committed <sprite name=FS_Criminal><color=#EA6B48>Crime</color>, the citizen might commit serious crimes.

The criminal can be arrested directly or by <sprite name=FS_CrimX><color=#EA6B48>Police</color> to be resocialized to prevent from commiting additional crimes.

When <sprite name=FS_Happiness><color=#EA6B48>Happiness</color> gets too low, then the disgruntled ratizens begin to incite rebellion.

After a certain amount of time, all of the agitated ratizens who are not happy enough will <sprite name=FS_Torch><color=#c83232>Revolt</color>.

<sprite name=FS_Torch><color=#c83232>Rebellion</color> will not end until a certain amount of time has elapsed or until all rebels have been suppressed.

Ratizens with high enough <sprite name=FS_Happiness><color=#EA6B48>Happiness</color> will not sympathize with the rebellion even if they are instigated.

<sprite name=FS_Prosperity><color=#EA6B48>Prosperity</color> is a measure of how developed the city is.

Prosperity is measured by adding the amount of currency in circulation, the number of ratizens by class, and the number of structures.

Build military structures such as <sprite name=FS_Military><color=#EA6B48>Training camp</color> or <sprite name=FS_Military><color=#EA6B48>Barrack</color> to train soldiers to defend your city.

It takes some <color=#EA6B48>training time</color> to turn a ratizen into a soldier.

Any soldiers, who finished training, can be placed in the<sprite name=FS_Military><color=#EA6B48>Squad Headquarter</color>.

Soldiers deployed at the <sprite name=FS_Military><color=#EA6B48>Squad Headquarter</color> can be commanded directly by the leader in <color=#C83232>Combat Mode</color>.

Ratizens who have low <sprite name=FS_Health>HP will enter the <sprite name=FS_Injury><color=#c83232>wounded state</color>!

The wounded ratizen can be transported to a <sprite name=FS_Base><color=#EA6B48>Bed</color> to recover, or can be healed with a <sprite name=FS_Service><color=#EA6B48>Hospital</color>.

Leaving the wounded ratizens unattended will result in their <sprite name=FS_Death><color=#c83232>death</color>.

When the <sprite name=FS_Death><color=#c83232>dead</color> are left unattended, it may adversely affect the surrounding ratizens.

With <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Grave</color> or <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Cemetery</color>, it is possible to honor the dead and memorialize them.

If there is an active <sprite name=FS_Service><color=#EA6B48>Hospital</color>, ratizens with low health will visit it to recover.

When a ratizen gets wounded, the ratizen assigned in the hospital will transport the wounded for treatment.

Each recovery costs a <color=#EA6B48>Medicine</color>.

When the <color=#EA6B48>Leader</color> is low in HP, rest on the <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Royal Bed</color> to recover.

The recovery will take a short time, but note that any other actions cannot be performed while recovering.

<sprite name=FS_Gold><color=#EA6B48>Government savings</color> is the amount of money that the leader can use.

When giving orders to ratizens or trading with the foreign countries, the money is spent from the savings.

If the savings run out, serious problems may arise.

<sprite name=FS_Property><color=#EA6B48>Ratizen's wealth</color> is the amount of money that the individual ratizens has.

Ratizens acquire incomes through the commands given by the player, and use them for their own happiness.

Ratizens with enough wealth and consumed necessities will rise in the social class.

<sprite name=FS_Tax><color=#EA6B48>Tax</color> is the most direct way to return ratizens' assets to the government savings.

It does not affect the total amount of money circulating in the country, but it is a way to balance the wealth concentrated on ratizens with the country.

However, ratizens who pay taxes will be dissatisfied.

<sprite name=FS_Gold><color=#EA6B48>Mintage</color> is the surest way to reliably increase the total amount of money circulates in the country.

It is essential to issue a certain amount of currency in order to build up enough government savings for the country and to satisfy enough wealth for ratizens.

<sprite name=FS_Loan><color=#EA6B48>Loan</color> is the fastest and easiest way to increase the currency in circulation in the country.

However, in exchange for this, interest must be paid periodically until the principal is repaid.

You can get a loan from the <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Bank</color>, but think carefully before using it.

<color=#EA6B48>Foreign currency</color> means <sprite name=FS_Dar><color=#33CC33>Dar</color>, a common currency used by most of the other countries.

<sprite name=FS_Dar><color=#33CC33>Dar</color> could be obtained by <color=#EA6B48>currency exchange</color> through a <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Bank</color>, or by trading with the other countries.

Dar's value changes dynamically according to the <sprite name=FS_Exchange><color=#EA6B48>Standard Exchange Rate</color>.

<sprite name=FS_Exchange><color=#EA6B48>Standard Exchange Rate</color> compares the monetary value between <sprite name=FS_Gold><color=#EA6B48>Pia</color> and <sprite name=FS_Dar><color=#33CC33>Dar</color>.

The monetary value between Pia and Dar is flexible and is updated every day by drawing one <sprite name=FS_ExchangeRate_GreatRise><color=#EA6B48>Exchange Rate Ticket</color>.

When exchanging Pia for Dar or Dar for Pia, the value is set according to this standard exchange rate.

Through the <sprite name=FS_Queen><color=#EA6B48>Bank</color>,  <sprite name=FS_Dar><color=#33CC33>Dar</color> to <sprite name=FS_Gold><color=#EA6B48>Pia</color>, or <sprite name=FS_Gold><color=#EA6B48>Pia</color> to <sprite name=FS_Dar><color=#33CC33>Dar</color> can be <sprite name=FS_Exchange><color=#EA6B48>exhanged</color>.

When buying Dar or selling Dar, there is a value added or subtracted in proportion to the standard exchange rate.

<sprite name=FS_ExchangeRate_GreatRise><color=#EA6B48>Exchange Rate Ticket</color> represents the possibilities of the exhange rate's changes.

Tickets other than the basic tickets can be obtained temporarily through various <color=#EA6B48>Events</color>.

Through exchange rate tickets, you can profit by stochastically adjusting the exchange rate or conduct trade advantageously.

<sprite name=FS_Trade><color=#EA6B48>Trade</color> is the act of purchasing from the other countries or selling unnecessary goods to the other countries.

Items can be traded based on <sprite name=FS_Prosperity><color=#EA6B48>Prosperity</color> of the target country and <sprite name=FS_Relations><color=#EA6B48>Relations</color> with the player. 

The trade cycle, however, is determined by the distance between countries.

<sprite name=FS_ElectricPower><color=#EA6B48>Electricity</color> is a special resource needed to operate certain engineering structures.

It is produced through <sprite name=FS_MakeWatt><color=#EA6B48>Generating Electricity</color> structures and must be stored in <sprite name=FS_Battery><color=#EA6B48>Electricity Storage</color> structures to be used.

<sprite name=FS_MakeWatt><color=#EA6B48>Generating Electricity</color> is the action of producing electricity using structures.

Generators produce a specified amount of electricity every hour or upon completion of work, depending on the method of generation.

<sprite name=FS_DirectElecLine><color=#EA6B48>Transmission</color> is the method of delivering generated electricity to storage.

The power ports of the generator and the electricity storage must be directly connected, or through <color=#EA6B48>Transmission Wires</color> and <color=#EA6B48>Transmission Blocks</color>, for the produced electricity to be fully stored in the storage.

<sprite name=FS_Battery><color=#EA6B48>Electricity Storage</color> is the function of storing electricity produced at the generators.

Stored electricity is supplied to nearby <sprite name=FS_UseWatt><color=#EA6B48>Electricity Consumption</color> structures.

The more connected electricity storage structures there are, the greater the amount of electricity that can be stored within the <sprite name=FS_ElecNetwork><color=#EA6B48>Electric Grid</color>.

<sprite name=FS_ElecNetwork><color=#EA6B48>Electric Grid</color> is a network that performs the production, storage, and consumption of electricity based on connected electricity storage structures.

Generation, storage, and consumption structures belonging to each electric grid can be viewed and managed using the <sprite name=FS_Statistics><color=#EA6B48>Statistics Window</color>.

<sprite name=FS_UseWatt><color=#EA6B48>Electricity Consumption</color> is the action of using stored electricity.

Structures that consume <sprite name=FS_ElectricPower><color=#EA6B48>Electricity</color> automatically connect to the storage if they are within its effective range.

Most electricity consumption structures consume electricity every hour, and if the connection is broken or there is no electricity to consume, the structure will be <color=#EA6B48>deactivated</color>.

When you activate a <color=#EA6B48>신단</color>Shrine, you can use the <color=#EA6B48>unique skills</color> of each Shrine.

Skills can be used via the [Skill] button, and all used skills have a <color=#EA6B48>cooldown</color> period.

Skills with a <color=#EA6B48>Hold</color> effect continue while the [Skill] button is pressed.

Skills with a <color=#EA6B48>Charge</color> effect are enhanced while the [Skill] button is pressed and activate when the input stops.
